    <step>10. To serve, spread a layer of ricotta cheese about 1/8 inch thick onto each cracker. Scatter a few edible flowers over the ricotta and sprinkle with sea salt.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Wilted Chard With Shallots and Vinegar</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 bunch Swiss chard</ingredient>
    <ingredient>ribs and stems separated from leaves'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 large shallots</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thinly sliced into rings'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 garlic cloves</ingredient>
    <ingredient>grated'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 teaspoons Sherry vinegar or red wine vinegar']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Cut Swiss chard stems into very small pieces. Tear leaves into 2" pieces and rinse well (you'll want some water still clinging to the leaves).</step>
    <step>2. Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high. Add chard stems, shallots, and garlic and season with salt. Cook, stirring occasionally, until vegetables are starting to soften but haven't taken on any color, about 2 minutes. Add chard leaves, season with salt, and cook, tossing occasionally, until leaves are tender and have released some liquid, about 3 minutes (stems will have a bit of crunch). Mix in vinegar</step>
    <step>3. taste and season with more salt if needed.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Celery Slaw with Seeds and Dates</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1/4 cup brown mustard seeds'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/3 cup unseasoned rice vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 small shallot</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thinly sliced'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/3 cup olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup unseasoned rice vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons soy sauce'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 Persian cucumbers'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 bunch mature arugula</ingredient>
    <ingredient>tough stems trimmed (about 8 cups)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 celery stalks</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thinly sliced on a diagonal</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus 1 cup celery leaves'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'10 Medjool dates</ingredient>
    <ingredient>sliced'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Toasted sesame seeds (for serving)']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Place mustard seeds in a small heatproof jar or bowl. Bring vinegar, sugar, and salt to a simmer in a small saucepan over medium-high heat, stirring to dissolve sugar and salt. Pour brine over mustard seeds and let cool, about 2 hours.</step>
    <step>2. Bring shallot and oil to a simmer in a small saucepan over medium heat. Cook 1 minute (watch it carefully</step>
    <step>3. you don’t want the shallot to take on any color). Let cool, then pour oil through a fine-mesh sieve into a small bowl</step>
    <step>4. discard shallot.</step>
    <step>5. Whisk shallot oil, vinegar, soy sauce, and sugar in a small bowl to combine</step>
    <step>6. season vinaigrette with salt.</step>
    <step>7. Trim ends from cucumbers and very thinly slice lengthwise on a mandoline or with a vegetable peeler or sharp knife into long ribbons. Toss cucumbers, arugula, celery, celery leaves, and dates in a large bowl to combine.</step>
    <step>8. Drizzle half of dressing over slaw and add 2 Tbsp. drained pickled mustard seeds (save remaining mustard seeds for another use) and toss again to coat. Taste and season with salt.</step>
    <step>9. Transfer slaw to a platter and top with sesame seeds. Serve with remaining vinaigrette alongside.</step>
    <step>10. Mustard seeds can be pickled 1 week ahead. Cover and chill. Vinaigrette can be made 2 days ahead. Cover and chill. Bring to room temperature before using.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Brussels Sprouts with Shallots and Salt Pork</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 cup 1/4" cubes salt pork or pancetta (about 8 ounces)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 large shallots</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled</ingredient>
    <ingredient>quartered (about 1 1/2 cups)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 pounds brussels sprouts</ingredient>
    <ingredient>outer leaves removed</ingredient>
    <ingredient>trimmed</ingredient>
    <ingredient>halved'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1-2 tablespoons juice from jarred dill pickles']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Blanch salt pork in a large saucepan of boiling water for 1 minute. Using a slotted spoon, transfer salt pork to a paper towel- lined plate to drain. Set aside. DO AHEAD: Salt pork can be blanched 1 day ahead. Cover and chill.</step>
    <step>2. Cook salt pork in a large heavy skillet over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until about 3/4 cup fat is rendered, 10-12 minutes. Carefully strain drippings into a small bowl</step>
    <step>3. return 2 tablespoons drippings and pork to pan.</step>
    <step>4. Increase heat to medium-high and cook, stirring occasionally, until salt pork is browned and crisp, 5-6 minutes. Transfer to paper towels to drain.</step>
    <step>5. Reduce heat to medium. Add 2 tablespoons drippings to skillet</step>
    <step>6. add shallots, cut sides down. Cook, turning once or twice, until tender and browned, 10-12 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Transfer shallots to a serving platter.</step>
    <step>7. Increase heat to medium-high. Add 2 tablespoons more salt pork drippings to skillet. Working in 2 batches and adding 2 more tablespoons drippings between batches, cook brussels sprouts, turning occasionally, until tender and browned. Transfer brussels sprouts to platter with shallots. DO AHEAD: Shallots and brussels sprouts can be made 1 hour ahead. Let stand at room temperature. Rewarm shallots and brussels sprouts together in same skillet over medium heat before continuing.</step>
    <step>8. Drizzle shallots and brussels sprouts with 1 tablespoon pickle juice. Season to taste with salt and pepper and 1 tablespoon more pickle juice, if desired. Scatter salt pork over.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Tarragon-Caper Egg Salad Sandwiches with Smoked Salmon</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['6 hard-boiled large eggs</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon finely chopped shallot'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 teaspoons finely chopped fresh tarragon'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons drained capers</ingredient>
    <ingredient>rinsed and finely chopped'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup mayonnaise'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'6 (4- to 5-inch) soft round seeded rolls</ingredient>
    <ingredient>split'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'18 watercress sprigs</ingredient>
    <ingredient>tough stems discarded'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 lb sliced smoked salmon']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Mash eggs coarsely with a fork, then stir in shallot, tarragon, capers, mayonnaise, and salt and pepper to taste. Make sandwiches with rolls, egg salad, watercress, and salmon.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Cold Sesame Noodles with Broccoli and Kale</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 large head of broccoli</ingredient>
    <ingredient>cut into large florets with some stalk attached'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 garlic cloves</ingredient>
    <ingredient>1 finely grated</ingredient>
    <ingredient>1 thinly sliced</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 teaspoons sambal oelek'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon plus 1/2 cup sherry vinegar or red wine vinegar</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3/4 cup vegetable oil</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon kosher salt</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus more'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus more'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 scallions</ingredient>
    <ingredient>green parts only</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thinly sliced</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus more for serving'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 (3-inch) piece ginger</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled</ingredient>
    <ingredient>cut into 1-inch matchsticks'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 cups chopped Tuscan kale leaves'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 (10-ounce) packages fresh ramen noodles or 2 (3-ounce) packages dried'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Torn mint leaves and toasted sesame seeds (for serving)']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Preheat oven to 450°F. Toss broccoli with grated garlic, sambal oelek, 1 Tbsp. vinegar, and 1/4 cup oil on a rimmed baking sheet</step>
    <step>2. season with salt and pepper. Roast, tossing occasionally, until tender and browned in spots, 20–25 minutes.</step>
    <step>3. Meanwhile, whisk scallions, ginger, sliced garlic, 1 tsp. salt, 1/4 tsp. pepper, and remaining 1/2 cup vinegar and 1/2 cup oil in a large bowl. Add kale</step>
    <step>4. toss to coat. Let sit at room temperature at least 15 minutes and up to 1 hour.</step>
    <step>5. Cook noodles according to package directions. Drain</step>
    <step>6. rinse under cold water. Add noodles and warm broccoli to kale and toss to coat. Divide among bowls and top with mint, sesame seeds, and more scallions.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Dark Chocolate Souffles With Cardamom Crème Anglaise</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['5 ounces bittersweet chocolate</ingredient>
    <ingredient>chopped'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon unsalted butter'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup plus 3 tablespoons sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons all purpose flour'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon unsweetened cocoa powder'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3/4 cup whole milk'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 large egg yolks'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'5 large egg whites'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 teaspoon coarse kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Cardamom Crème Anglaise']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Place chocolate and butter in medium bowl. Whisk 1/4 cup sugar, flour, and cocoa powder in small bowl. Bring milk and vanilla to boil in heavy small saucepan. Gradually whisk hot milk mixture into sugar mixture to blend. Return mixture to same saucepan. Cook over medium-high heat until thick paste forms, stirring constantly, about 2 minutes. Scrape mixture into bowl with chocolate and butter</step>
    <step>2. stir until chocolate is melted (mixture may look curdled). Add egg yolks and whisk until mixture looks shiny and creamy. (Soufflé base can be prepared 1 day ahead. Press plastic wrap directly onto surface and refrigerate. Bring soufflé base to room temperature before continuing.)</step>
    <step>3. Butter eight 3/4-cup soufflé dishes or custard cups</step>
    <step>4. dust with sugar. Using electric mixer, beat egg whites until frothy. With mixer running, gradually add 3 tablespoons sugar, then salt</step>
    <step>5. beat just until soft peaks form. Fold 1/3 of whites into soufflé base until well combined. Gently fold in remaining egg whites just to blend (some white streaks may remain). Divide batter among prepared dishes. Place dishes on rimmed baking sheet. (Can be prepared 2 hours ahead. Let stand at room temperature.)</step>
    <step>6. Preheat oven to 350°F. Bake soufflés until puffed above rim of dish, tops are flat, and edges are set, about 12 minutes. Serve immediately with Cardamom Crème Anglaise.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Persian Steamed White Rice (Chelo)</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['5 cups basmati rice</ingredient>
    <ingredient>checked and rinsed'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'12 cups water'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup canola oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4-inch canola oil poured into the bottom of the saucepan'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons water'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 teaspoon turmeric or powdered saffron (optional</ingredient>
    <ingredient>for a more authentic flavor)']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Fill a large nonstick saucepan (at least 6 quarts) with 12 cups water</step>
    <step>2. add oil and salt. Cover and bring to a brisk boil over high heat.</step>
    <step>3. Add the rice and continue cooking over medium to high heat, stirring occasionally.</step>
    <step>4. After 3-5 minutes, use a slotted spoon to scoop some grains from the water. Break one grain in half to make sure it is "al dente" (see above). Turn off the heat and pour rice into the colander to drain</step>
    <step>5. set aside.</step>
    <step>6. Place the empty 6-quart saucepan back onto the stovetop over medium heat. Add 1/4-inch canola oil and 2 tablespoons water. Add turmeric and/or saffron powder. Stir together.</step>
    <step>7. Add the drained rice and shape it into a pyramid. Cover the pot and cook for 5-7 minutes until rice begins to steam.</step>
    <step>8. Uncover and place 2 paper towels (one on top of the other) over the rice. The ends will extend outside the pot. Replace the lid tightly.</step>
    <step>9. Reduce heat to low and simmer, covered, for 45 minutes. Turn off the heat and tilt the lid until ready to serve.</step>
    <step>10. With a wide spatula, scoop the rice from the pot, making sure not to disturb the crust (tadig) that formed on the bottom of the pot. Serve the rice on a flat serving platter, mounding it into the shape of a pyramid. Turn the tadig out onto a flat serving platter by inverting the pot, as you would invert a cake pan, or cut it into pieces and serve around the rice.</step>
    <step>11. To make saffron water, mix together 1 teaspoon crushed saffron threads and 1/4 cup hot water. Steep for a few minutes, until the water becomes yellow.</step>
    <step>12. Mix saffron water with steamed white rice. Use this intensely yellow rice to make designs on the Chelo.</step>
    <step>13. Pour 1/2 cup water mixed with 1/4 cup canola oil onto the pyramid in a large pot. You can also freeze this rice, as long as you do not stir it until it is completely defrosted. You can even cook it, freeze it, and later steam it as it defrosts. I know I will have to spend time in "rice hell" for admitting to freezing Persian rice, but it is worth it to make my life easier!</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>
